import keyConceptsImage from './assets/images/key-concepts.png'; import componentsImage from './assets/images/components.png'; import stateImage from './assets/images/state.png'; import eventsImage from './assets/images/events.png'; import components from "./assets/images/components.png" import event from "./assets/images/events.png" import keyconcepts from "./assets/images/key-concepts.png" import state from "./assets/images/state.png" const concepts = [ { title: 'Components', image: componentsImage, description: 'Components let you split the UI into independent, reusable pieces, and think about each piece in isolation. Components can receive data via props, and they can render dynamic output using JSX.', }, { title: 'State', image: stateImage, description: 'State is data that may change over time. As it changes, the UI should be updated to reflect the updated data. Each component can maintain its own state and multiple components can share state.', }, { title: 'Events', image: eventsImage, description: 'Event handlers are added via props to (built-in) components. You pass functions as values to such event handlers to control which functions gets executed for which event.', }, ]; function App() { return (

Key React Concepts

Selected key React concepts you should know about

  • Components

    In React, components are the building blocks of user interfaces. They allow you to split your UI into independent, reusable pieces, making your code more modular and maintainable. Components are at the core of React's declarative and component-based architecture. There are two main types of components in React: functional components and class components.

  • events

    In React, events allow you to capture interactions such as user actions (e.g., clicking a button, typing in an input field) and respond to them by invoking specific functions. Events in React are similar to DOM events but have some differences due to React's synthetic event system.

  • keyconcepts

    In React, there are several key concepts that form the foundation of building user interfaces. These concepts are fundamental to understanding how React works and how to effectively develop applications using the library.

  • state

    In React, state is a built-in feature that represents the dynamic data managed within a component. It allows a component to keep track of changing information and render UI based on that information. State is used to create interactive and dynamic user interfaces.

); } export default App;
